title: New Report: Trump To OK DHS Plan For More, Faster Deportations
text:
New Report: Trump To OK DHS Plan For More, Faster Deportations "I said it Day 1 ..." by Jack Davis February 21, 2017 at 9:07am Share on Facebook 521 Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
President Donald Trump’s campaign promise to crack down on illegal immigration will move into high gear Tuesday as the White House prepares what one media report calls a “big immigration launch.” 
Fox News reported that Trump will announce his decision to move forward with a recent Department of Homeland Security proposal that called for adding agents and faster deportations. 
The plan proposed by DHS Secretary John Kelly called for 10,000 additional Immigration and Customs Enforcement staff and 5,000 new hires at the U.S. Customs and Border Protection agency. Advertisement - story continues below Democrats Discuss Using 25th Amendment To Remove ‘Unstable’ Trump From Office 
“The surge of immigration at the southern border has overwhelmed federal agencies and resources and has created a significant national security vulnerability to the United States,” Kelly wrote. 
Former President Barack Obama had previously issued executive orders that supported deporting illegal immigrants with criminal records and terrorist connections. 
“Criminal aliens have demonstrated their disregard for the rule of law and pose a threat to persons residing in the United States,” Kelly wrote. “As such criminal aliens are a priority for removal.” Advertisement – story continues below 
In its reporting on the DHS proposals, the New York Times reported that the proposals expand the scope of an existing expedited removal program. Under the Obama administration, the program was focused on illegal immigrants 100 miles of the border who had been in the U.S. for up to two weeks. 
Kelly’s plan expands that to cover illegal immigrants located anywhere in the United States who have been in America for up to two years. 
Although the Times reported that the memo would not target children of illegal immigrants who were born in America, it left open the potential prosecution of their parents. Advertisement - story continues below
